Pat Farrell wrote:

>Michael Feathers wrote:
>  
>
>> >I want one MasterControlDaemon, not two. I want one "TrueDefaultPolicy"
>> >for when we look up a FooPolicy and can't find it, we get something
>> >more useful than a null pointer. We can subclass, the GrandpaFooPolicy
>> >can subclass from the "TrueDefaultPolicy" and the FooPolicy can extend
>> >the GrandpaFooPolicy, but you need a concrete instance of a base, and
>> >you really only want one of them.
>> 
>>It's reasonable to want only one of an object, but for me it comes down
>>to one question: can I trust my team members not to create two? If I
>>can, it makes sense to avoid the singleton. The enforcement that
>>singleton brings is the solution to a problem, but the problem is social
>>not technical. It pays to know whether you have the problem or not.
>>    
>>
>
>In short, no, I do not trust the team members. Nor do I trust the JVM.
>
>Teams are rarely made of just smart, dedicated, senior people. And even 
>the best make mistakes, see Murphy's Law. So the good engineering 
>response to Murphy, who was a real engineer, is to reduce the chance 
>that folks can do things wrong. Even when the team is only me, I'm not 
>sure it is wise to 'trust the team'
>  
>
Pat, the thing is, I think we can generalize in either direction on this 
and it's dangerous either way. 

We could say all applications are worked on by outstanding engineers who 
can remember what they are supposed to do or not do in the code base, or 
we can say all applications are absolutely critical and we can't trust 
ourselves or our coworkers not to make mistakes so we must do everything 
possible to avoid them. 

The fact of that matter is, all people and all applications are 
different.  There are teams and applications with which I wouldn't 
hesitate to "just create one" rather than use a singleton, and there are 
teams and applications where I wouldn't do that simply because the team 
isn't a team or the application is so critical that spurious creation of 
an object could cause disaster.

I think that we have to examine each situation for the cues that we need 
to make engineering decisions.  Otherwise they aren't really decisions.
